examples.title: Area of a Parabolic Segment
examples.statement: Show that the area of a parabolic segment (the region bounded by a parabola and a chord) is $\frac{4}{3}$ times the area of the inscribed triangle with the same base and vertex at the point where the tangent is parallel to the chord.

steps.title: Set up coordinates
steps.content: Place the parabola as $y = x^2$ with the chord along the $x$-axis from $x = -a$ to $x = a$. The vertex of the inscribed triangle is at $(0, 0)$ where the tangent $y' = 2x = 0$ is horizontal (parallel to the chord).

steps.title: Calculate triangle area
steps.content: The inscribed triangle has base $2a$ and height $a^2$, so its area is $\frac{1}{2} \cdot 2a \cdot a^2 = a^3$.

steps.title: Calculate parabolic segment area
steps.content: The parabolic segment area is $\int_{-a}^{a} (a^2 - x^2)\,dx = \left[a^2 x - \frac{x^3}{3}\right]_{-a}^{a} = 2a^3 - \frac{2a^3}{3} = \frac{4a^3}{3}$.

solution.conclusion: This is Archimedes' famous result, derived over 2000 years before calculus was formally developed. He proved it using the method of exhaustion.

examples.title: Archimedes' Method
examples.statement: Use inscribed and circumscribed rectangles to approximate the area under $y = x^2$ from $x = 0$ to $x = b$.

steps.title: Partition the interval
steps.content: Divide $[0, b]$ into $n$ equal subintervals, each of width $\Delta x = b/n$. The partition points are $x_k = kb/n$ for $k = 0, 1, \ldots, n$.

solution.conclusion: The area under $y = x^2$ from $0$ to $b$ is $\frac{b^3}{3}$. This is the method of exhaustion in action.

steps.title: Set up the approximation
steps.content: Partition $[0, b]$ into $n$ equal parts with $\Delta x = b/n$ and $x_k = kb/n$.

steps.title: Union
steps.content: $A \cup B = \{x : x \in A \text{ or } x \in B\} = \{1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6\}$

steps.title: Intersection
steps.content: $A \cap B = \{x : x \in A \text{ and } x \in B\} = \{3, 4\}$

steps.title: Set difference A - B
steps.content: $A - B = \{x : x \in A \text{ and } x \notin B\} = \{1, 2\}$

steps.title: Set difference B - A
steps.content: $B - A = \{x : x \in B \text{ and } x \notin A\} = \{5, 6\}$

solution.conclusion: Note that $A \cup B$ can be written as the disjoint union $(A - B) \cup (A \cap B) \cup (B - A)$.

exercises.statement: Prove that $A \subseteq B$ if and only if $A \cap B = A$.

steps.title: Forward direction
steps.content: Assume $A \subseteq B$. We always have $A \cap B \subseteq A$. For the reverse, if $x \in A$, then $x \in B$ (since $A \subseteq B$), so $x \in A \cap B$. Thus $A \subseteq A \cap B$, and therefore $A = A \cap B$.

steps.title: Reverse direction
steps.content: Assume $A \cap B = A$. If $x \in A$, then $x \in A \cap B$ (since $A = A \cap B$), so $x \in B$. Thus $A \subseteq B$.

solution.conclusion: $A \subseteq B \Leftrightarrow A \cap B = A$

examples.title: Field Axioms
examples.statement: Using only the field axioms, prove that $(-a)(-b) = ab$ for all real numbers $a$ and $b$.

solution.conclusion: $(-a)(-b) = ab$. The product of two negatives is positive.

steps.title: Assume $a \neq 0$
steps.content: If $a \neq 0$, then $a$ has a multiplicative inverse $a^{-1}$.

solution.conclusion: Therefore $b = 0$. If $a \neq 0$, then $b = 0$; equivalently, $a = 0$ or $b = 0$.

exercises.statement: Prove that $|ab| = |a| \cdot |b|$ for all real numbers $a$ and $b$.

steps.title: Case 2: One negative
steps.content: If $a < 0$ and $b \geq 0$, then $ab \leq 0$, so $|ab| = -ab = (-a)b = |a| \cdot |b|$. Similarly if $a \geq 0$ and $b < 0$.

solution.conclusion: In all cases, $|ab| = |a| \cdot |b|$.

exercises.statement: Prove the triangle inequality: $|a + b| \leq |a| + |b|$ for all real $a, b$.

steps.title: Establish bounds on $a$ and $b$
steps.content: By definition of absolute value: $-|a| \leq a \leq |a|$ and $-|b| \leq b \leq |b|$.

steps.title: Apply absolute value definition
steps.content: The inequality $-c \leq x \leq c$ (for $c \geq 0$) is equivalent to $|x| \leq c$.

solution.conclusion: Therefore $|a + b| \leq |a| + |b|$.

exercises.statement: Prove that for any nonempty set $S$ of real numbers bounded above, $\sup S$ is unique.

steps.title: Assume two supremums
steps.content: Suppose $M$ and $M'$ are both supremums of $S$.

steps.title: Apply least upper bound property
steps.content: Since $M$ is the least upper bound and $M'$ is an upper bound, $M \leq M'$. Similarly, since $M'$ is the least upper bound and $M$ is an upper bound, $M' \leq M$.

solution.conclusion: The supremum is unique when it exists.

examples.title: Strong Induction
examples.statement: Prove that every integer $n \geq 2$ can be written as a product of primes.

steps.title: Base case
steps.content: For $n = 2$: $2$ is prime, so it is a product of primes (a single prime).

steps.title: Strong inductive hypothesis
steps.content: Assume every integer $k$ with $2 \leq k < n$ can be written as a product of primes.

steps.title: Inductive step
steps.content: If $n$ is prime, we're done. If $n$ is composite, then $n = ab$ for some integers $a, b$ with $2 \leq a, b < n$. By the inductive hypothesis, both $a$ and $b$ are products of primes, so $n = ab$ is also a product of primes.

solution.conclusion: By strong induction, every integer $n \geq 2$ is a product of primes.
By induction, $\sum_{i=1}^{n} i = \frac{n(n+1)}{2}$ for all $n \geq 1$.

steps.title: Base case
steps.content: For $n = 4$: $4! = 24$ and $2^4 = 16$. Since $24 > 16$, the base case holds.

solution.conclusion: By induction, $n! > 2^n$ for all $n \geq 4$.

exercises.statement: Use the well-ordering principle to prove there is no integer between 0 and 1.

steps.title: Apply well-ordering
steps.content: If $S$ is nonempty, let $m$ be the smallest positive integer in $S$ (exists by well-ordering).

steps.title: Derive contradiction
steps.content: Then $0 < m < 1$, so $0 < m^2 < m < 1$. But $m^2$ is a positive integer (being $m \cdot m$) in $S$ smaller than $m$, contradicting minimality.

solution.conclusion: Therefore $S$ is empty; there is no integer strictly between 0 and 1.

steps.title: Use binomial theorem
steps.content: The binomial theorem states $(1 + x)^n = \sum_{k=0}^{n} \binom{n}{k} x^k$.

solution.conclusion: Therefore $\sum_{k=0}^{n} \binom{n}{k} = 2^n$. Combinatorially: this counts all subsets of an $n$-element set.
Therefore $\sum_{k=0}^{n} (-1)^k \binom{n}{k} = 0$ for $n \geq 1$. This means the number of even-sized subsets equals the number of odd-sized subsets.
